name: Loprazolam
summary: A benzodiazepine hypnotic used primarily for the short-term treatment of insomnia.
description: Loprazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine hypnotic with anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, and anticonvulsant properties. It is primarily indicated for the short-term management of severe insomnia and sleep disturbances. Its relatively short half-life makes it suitable for patients who have difficulty falling asleep without significant next-day sedation when used appropriately.

sections.text: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor complex, increasing chloride influx into neurons and producing sedative and anxiolytic effects.

adult.insomnia: 1–2 mg orally at bedtime; maximum 2 mg/day

sections.geriatric: Start with 0.5–1 mg at bedtime; monitor closely for excessive sedation
sections.hepatic_impairment: Avoid in severe impairment; lower dose in mild/moderate impairment
sections.renal_impairment: No specific adjustment, but use caution in severe impairment

sections.text: Onset within 30 minutes; duration of action about 6–8 hours.

other: Risk of dependence and withdrawal with prolonged use
May cause complex sleep-related behaviors (e.g., sleep-driving)
Avoid alcohol and other CNS depressants

items: Signs of misuse, abuse, or dependence

sections.pregnancy: Avoid unless benefits outweigh risks; risk of neonatal withdrawal or floppy infant syndrome
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; avoid use
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to sedatives; start at lowest dose

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over weeks to prevent withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia rebound, tremors, or seizures.

items: Intended for short-term use (≤4 weeks) to minimize dependence risk
Lower risk of next-day drowsiness compared to some longer-acting benzodiazepines
Efficacy may diminish with repeated use due to tolerance

seo.title: Loprazolam: Benzodiazepine Hypnotic for Insomnia
seo.description: Loprazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine hypnotic used for short-term management of insomnia, with rapid onset and low next-day sedation risk.
